quote: Doctor... ?
I don't know what it's doing to him, or what'll happen if we stop it...
He could be dying by inches...
His vital signs are stable. There's no indication he's in a life-threatening situation --
I'm not willing to let that thing keep drilling into him --
I simply don't know the risk of shutting down the beam. If someone gets stabbed, you don't necessarily pull the knife out right away -- that might do more harm than leaving it there.
The captain is under attack. We must act.
I'm inclined to agree. Doctor, monitor him closely. Mister Data, prepare to disrupt the beam. We're going to try to cut this cord.
Meribor, this is your brother's ceremony; now don't fidget.
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: We name this child for a dear friend who died last year... but who will now live on through his namesake.
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: We name you -- Batai. In his honor.
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: He's starting life in the warmth of friends. Thank you. Please, help yourselves to something to eat.
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: It seems like just yesterday that we had Meribor's naming ceremony.
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: I remember. I was so nervous I thought I might drop her. Now look at her... a little lady...
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: She's no lady... tromping through the hills with you all day, digging those soil samples you insist on collecting... she's her father's daughter.
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: What is it?
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: I'd always thought I didn't need children to make my life complete... now, I can't imagine life without them.
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: Kamin!
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: Get the doctor -- hurry!
scene: 42   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - DAY - ON PICARD

quote: I'm losing him!
I'm getting massive somatophysical failure...
Two cc's delactovine...
Data, get that beam back.
There are severe fluctuations in the isocortex... synaptic responses are failing...
Begin full cardiac induction...
Blood pressure is dropping rapidly... seventy over twenty --
Data, you have to reestablish that beam.
I am attempting to do so, Doctor.
Losing response in the isocortex --
Cortical stimulator...
Start at ten percent...
Doctor, the beam is fully restored.
Blood pressure up to ninety over forty... ... and rising...
Isocortical functions are stabilizing... vital signs approaching normal levels...
Meribor... ?
Happy day, father...
That's my hobby; find your own.
You're the one who taught me. Don't complain if you turned me into a scientist.
And what has the scientist been up to today?
Analyzing soil samples. There's not even any anerobic bacteria. The soil is dead.
This isn't just a long drought, is it? I have entries in my log that go back ten years. You have data that precedes that by fifteen years. You've reached the same conclusion, I know you have.
I haven't reached any conclusion. A good scientist doesn't function by conjecture.
A good scientist functions by hypothesizing and then proving or disproving that hypothesis. That's what I've done.
Tell me... why don't you spend more time with that young fellow Dannick?
You're changing the subject.
I'm not; I'm hypothesizing that he's in love with you.
You've taught me to pursue the truth -- no matter how painful it might be. It's too late to back off from that.
I've analyzed the rings in old trees. I've examined rock strata to correlate evidence of climactic changes over the centuries. Father -- this planet is dying.
Perhaps I should have filled your head with trivial concerns... games and toys and clothes...
I don't think you mean that.
No... but it saddens me to see you bear the burden of knowing things... things you can't change.
It's no more a burden than you bear.
But I'm not sixteen. With my life ahead of me.
Father? I think I should marry Dannick sooner rather than later... don't you?
I can only say... ... Live now, Meribor. Always make "now" the most precious time. "Now" will not come again.
I love you, father.
Vital signs are holding... he's been stable ever since the beam was restored. I don't know what more to do for him.
Commander, we're starting to receive telemetry from the probe we launched.
Go ahead.
We've charted the alien probe's radiation trail for just over one light year.
Can you extrapolate a point of origin?
Our best guess would be a star system in the Silarian sector... Kataan.
Kataan... I've never heard of it. Data... ?
It is an unmapped system of six planets.
Any of them inhabited?
Not any longer, sir. The star went nova. All life in the system was destroyed approximately one thousand years ago.
I put your shoes away for you again.
Ah. Thank you, dear.
I've been looking through this thing off and on for almost thirty years... and I still can't see what you and Meribor find so fascinating.
Fine. Then maybe you'll sit down and rest the way you're supposed to.
(relinquishing the telescope) You treat me like some frail flower. People have surgery all the time.
He loves playing. And he's very good at it, you know.
He loves doing a lot of things -- too many. One week he wants to be a botanist, the next week a sculptor. I wish he could find some focus in his life.
I think he has.
Maybe you should talk to him.
Batai?
Father... ?
I get the feeling from your mother that you have something to tell me.
Yes. I was waiting for the right moment... but that won't ever come. I'm leaving school.
Leaving school -- ? No, you're not --
I want to concentrate on my music. It's what I care about.
Last year, all you cared about was mathematics. A year before that it was botany. Now --
But through it all there was my music. I think you know that, father... This is the life I want.
We'll... we'll discuss it.
Thank you, father.
Even after all these years... you have the ability to surprise me.
If music is what he wants... why should I stand in his way? Who knows how much time he'll have to follow any dream.
Are you still planning to talk to the Administrator tomorrow?
Yes. It's possible he'll dismiss me from the Council.
Unless, of course, you keep quiet.
The evidence is too pronounced. I can't stay silent.
What a surprise.
Kamin, what do you hope to accomplish? Spreading rumors that the planet is doomed... there could be chaos.
The facts are here. At least show them to someone who will recognize what they mean.
I won't be a party to your making trouble --
If you won't take them, I most certainly will.
Your observations... your findings... our scientists reached those same conclusions two years ago.
Well, what did you expect us to do? Make it public? Can you imagine the effect... ?
Surely the technology exists to save something of this world... perhaps some people could be evacuated...
Evacuated to where? Our technology is limited. We're just beginning to launch small missiles...
A collection of genetic samples, then -- something, anything -- you can't just let this civilization die --
Enough! There is a plan in the works. I can't tell you more than that.
Father!
What is it -- ?
It's mother. Hurry.
Doctor -- ?
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: You see... I'll go to any lengths... to get your attention.
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: You always had a flair for the dramatic...
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: Doctor... Batai... leave us alone for a moment. I want to talk to my husband.
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: Did the Administrator look at your evidence?
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: He didn't have to. They already know.
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: So he didn't throw you off the Council...
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: No...
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: Remember -- put your shoes away.
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: I will.
scene: 73   INT. KAMIN MAIN ROOM - MINUTES LATER

quote: Doctor...
What is it?
I'm not sure. He's showing physiological alterations... His systemic readings are changing...
So are his respiratory functions.
Is he in danger?
I don't know... I don't understand what's happening. The changes are subtle, but...
... If I didn't know better, I'd say these are the metabolic rates of an eighty-year-old man.
Some children are certainly making a lot of noise in here.
You shouldn't be out there for so long. It's damaging, you know that.
I'm wearing plenty of your skin protector.
Mmnph. Do you wear your skin protector outdoors, young man?
Happy day, everybody! It's time to go see the launching.
What "launching"? What's he talking about?
They're sending up a missile, father. We're going to watch it.
Are we, indeed. I'm not going anywhere to watch anything.
Come on, Kamie; let's go see the launching.
Breaks my heart to look at him...
Who?
My grandson. Breaks my heart... he deserves a full rich life, and he's not going to get one.
He's my child, and I tell you he is getting one. I wish it could be longer, but it's as full and rich as we can possibly make it.
Please come, father.
Why didn't I hear anything about a launching?
Did everyone know about this except me?
I can see all right from here.
You go on with the others. Go hold onto my grandson, and watch the damned thing go up... for all the good it'll do. What is it they're launching?
You know about it, father. You've already seen it.
Seen it? What are you talking about? I haven't seen any missile.
Yes, you have, old friend... Don't you remember?
Batai?
You saw it... just before you came here.
We hoped our probe would encounter someone in the future -- someone who could be a teacher... who could tell others about us.
A probe... that encounters someone...
... someone in the future... ... it's me, isn't it? I'm the someone...
I'm the one it finds... that's what this launching is -- a probe that finds me... in the future...
Yes, my love...
Eline...
The rest of us have been gone for a thousand years...
If you remember what we were, and how we lived... then we'll have found life again.
Eline...
Now we live. In you. Tell them of us... my darling...
Something's happening...
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: The nucleonic beam has ceased, Commander. The probe has shut down.
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: His cerebral functions are stabilizing.
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: Mister Worf, put a tractor beam on the probe. I want it in shuttlebay two for examination.
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: Yes, Commander.
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: What...
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: Please, Captain... don't get up too quickly...
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: How long? How long have I been... like this?
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: At least twenty, maybe twenty-five minutes.
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: Twenty-five minutes?
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: Captain, I need you in sickbay now. I want to run a full diagnostic.
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: Very well, Doctor. But as soon as you're done... I have a great deal to tell you.
scene: 87   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD'S FACE

quote: Come.
Hello, sir. Feeling better?
Yes, thank you... but I find I'm having to remind myself that this -- -- is really my home.
We were able to open the probe and examine it. Whatever it was that locked onto you must have been self-terminating. It isn't functional any longer.
We found this inside.
Captain's Log, Stardate 46154.2. The Enterprise has entered the Amargosa Diaspora, an unusually dense globular cluster. We are faced with the daunting task of charting this vast region.
Lieutenant Shipley -- let's get a triangulation on these sector points...
Aye sir.
Sorry I'm late... I overslept again... What have you got?
The cluster's a lot more dense than we thought. It's going to take three days just to map one tenth of it.
Three days?
I think we've found a way to speed this up. We've been testing a method of channeling warp energy to the main deflector grid. It enhances the long-range sensors...
The modification would increase our sensor efficiency and imaging resolution by twenty-five percent or more.
Sounds like that would take a lot of warp energy...
We'd channel it through the EPS mains on Deck Thirteen... near Cargo Bay Four.
It's worth a try.
Data, let's get those subspace field taps on-line...
Commander -- I would like to remind you about my poetry reading this afternoon.
Wouldn't miss it for the world.
I can hardly wait to see what he came up with...

"Then we sat on the sand for some time and observed How the oceans that cover this world were perturbed By the tides from the orbiting moon overhead 'How relaxing the sound of the waves is,' you said. "I began to expound upon tidal effects When you told me to stop, looking somewhat perplexed So I did not explain why the sunset turned red And we watched the occurrence in silence instead."
I don't understand this... I can barely keep my eyes open...

That poem was written in anapestic tetrameter. For my ninth poem, we move to the iambic septameter mode. Throughout the ages, from Keats to Jorkemo, poets have composed odes to the individuals who have had a profound effect on their lives. In keeping with that tradition, I have written my next poem in honor of my cat. I call it "Ode to Spot."
"Felis catus is your taxonomic nomenclature An endothermic quadruped, carnivorous by nature Your visual, olfactory, and auditory senses Contribute to your hunting skill and natural defenses."

"I find myself intrigued by your sub-vocal oscillations A singular development of cat communication That obviates your basic hedonistic predilection For a rhythmic stroking of your fur to demonstrate affection... "

"A tail is quite essential for your acrobatic talents You would not be so agile if you lacked its counterbalance And when not being utilized to aid in locomotion It often serves to illustrate the state of your emotions."
You have prematurely anticipated my denouement, Commander. However, I appreciate the sentiment. I will continue.

"Oh Spot, the complex level of behavior you display Connotes a fairly well-developed cognitive array And though you are not sentient, Spot, and do not comprehend I nonetheless consider you a true and valued friend... "
I don't have any problem getting to sleep... and I think I'm sleeping all night... but when I wake up, I feel exhausted...
How long has this been going on?
The last two, three nights...
Do you have to hold that thing so close?
I'm sorry... I've been on edge all day.
Other than some muscle tension in your neck, I don't see anything wrong with you physically... Have you been having bad dreams?
Not that I can remember...
This may be the result of a lack of REM sleep...
What do you recommend?
Drink this before you go to bed.
What is it?
A recipe for a warm milk toddy.
Warm milk toddy... you're kidding.
The heat activates amino acids in the lactose -- which acts as a natural sedative. Besides, this is a recipe of the Captain's Aunt Adelle. It's delicious.
At this point, I'll give anything a try. Thanks.
Everything's in place... deflector grid couplers... subspace field taps... Let's do it. Lieutenant Shipley -- initiate warp power transfer...
Aye sir... Sensor array on-line...
Come on... work...
Geordi -- active scanner output has increased by twenty-six percent.
Inform Astrophysics that the new La Forge sensor array is on-line and awaiting major scientific discoveries.
Yes sir.
Geordi... may I make a personal inquiry? It concerns my poetry reading.
Sure, Data... what is it?
I noticed that many spectators seemed distracted during my presentation. Was my poetry uninteresting?
Well... it was very well constructed... a real tribute to form... I especially liked your Haiku poem...
My Haiku was only three lines long.
Yeah... it was great... very... brisk...
Brisk... Geordi, are you saying that the shorter my poems, the better?
No... well... sort of... To be honest, Data... some of your longer poems were a little dry.
Maybe some of your poems were a little... formal.
I have found poetry more challenging than other artistic endeavors. Unlike painting and musical composition, it demands a more articulated emotional content.
Next time, don't worry so much about rhyme and meter. Some of the world's greatests poets didn't pay attention to rules...
That's the power grid warning...
I am reading a massive EPS explosion.
Where?
I am attempting to localize it... It is Cargo Bay Four.
I've got three people down there! Damage control, medical team, to Cargo Bay Four! Let's go...
The field imbalance has subsided. I believe it is safe to enter.
There may still be a residual discharge. Stand clear.
Is there something wrong, sir?
We analyzed the power conduits -- there's no evidence of an EPS explosion.
Sensors seemed to think there was...
I think my modification to the sensor array may have caused a pattern recognition failure.
Just a sensor glitch?
That's my guess.
Perform a level three diagnostic on the internal sensor network. Make sure we haven't overlooked anything.
Aye sir.
Maybe we should pick this up in the morning, Mister La Forge -- get a fresh start. And would you do me a favor? Stop by my quarters at oh-seven hundred hours. I've been having trouble waking up.
Sure. Goodnight.
Goodnight.
Who is it?
Commander La Forge.
Good morning, sir.
Morning? I just went to bed...
Sir -- it's oh seven hundred hours.
Mister Worf! My good Klingon, sir, welcome. It's a pleasure to have you with us again... so... soon.
Haircut today, Lieutenant? Trim your beard?
I would like my hair trimmed.
Ah. A trim, of course...
Not like last time.
Oh no -- just a little off the top... took way too much off last time...
I was just telling my colleague Mister Setti how thick and luxuriant Klingon hair is... it's such a pleasure to cut, sometimes I get carried away...
All those Away Missions... wind... dry air... the elements are very harsh on the hair. I'd like to suggest you start using a conditioning agent...
I promise -- not too much off the top!
Just before the grid alarm sounded, we were running warp power through this junction... somehow, it must've tripped the internal scanners...
And they showed it as an EPS explosion...
The question is, why? I've made modifications to the sensors before... and nothing like this ever happened.
We can't waste time chasing down sensor ghosts. Keep the array off-line until you have a chance to take a closer look.
Aye sir...
I know the feeling... the past few nights, it seems the second my head hits the pillow, it's time to get up again.
We could all use some shore leave after this survey.
Definitely. Keep me informed.
Data, will you give me a hand? I've got to run a structural integrity scan. I want to make sure the conduit wasn't weakened by the --
Ow...
What is it?
This is the second time today my VISOR's cut out...
Are you alright, Geordi?
I don't know... I just had a weird feeling... I think I'd better get to Sickbay...
I will run the integrity scan.
Thanks...
This is curious... There's a slight bacterial infection around your neural inputs... it was probably interrupting the data stream.
Infection... from what?
It doesn't match any bacterial strains on record...
I'm going to sterilize the area... but I'll need to run a resonance tissue scan to look for signs of additional infection...
Come over here...
You'll need to hold still...
How's the scan going, Data?
I have just started the scan. I thought you were going to Sickbay.
I've been there for the past hour and a half.
That is not possible. My internal chronometer indicates it has been exactly one minute, fifteen seconds since you left the room.
I'm telling you, Data, I've been gone for over an hour.
Computer -- what time is it?
The time is fourteen twenty-seven hours.
You are correct. Ninety-two minutes, seventeen seconds have passed since you left the room.
What have you been doing all this time?
I have no memory of events during that period. When we are finished here, I will perform a self-diagnostic.

First we pick up a false EPS explosion... then my VISOR cuts out twice... now you lose an hour... all in the Cargo Bay... La Forge to Engineering -- I want a diagnostic team to Cargo Bay Two immediately.
On our way, sir.
Ensign Rager -- cartography needs a better position to study cluster FGC-thirteen. Bring us about, heading one twenty three mark four.
Aye sir. Helm won't lock to those coordinates, sir.
First time navigating through a globular cluster, Ensign?
You've got to compensate for gravimetric interference before you...
Sir... is there something wrong?
No... I don't know... Maintain your original course, Ensign...
Don't tell me...
This can't be right... Data, can you come take a look at this?
I think we've got another sensor glitch.
The sensors are functioning normally... They are detecting a subspace particle emission originating from within this room.
Within this room... that's not possible...
The emission is emanating from this direction...
Geordi...
(to Picard, re: bulkhead) The structure of the bulkhead is being altered on a subatomic level. The metal itself is in a state of quasi-molecular flux.
What's causing it?

This is where it gets pretty wild, Captain... Behind this panel, there's a junction we were using to transfer warp power to the sensor array. We're picking up a subspace particle stream emanating from that junction...
It appears to be composed of spatially-inverted tetryon particles. We believe they are emanating from a tertiary subspace manifold.
I thought tetryons were unstable in normal space...
We don't understand it either, sir.
Something from that deep in subspace shouldn't be able to exist in our universe... But here it is.
Does this pose a danger to the ship?
Not unless it spreads... if it does, we could beam the bulkhead into space and erect a forcefield in its place.
Keep that option ready. For now, proceed with the analysis.
Aye sir.
When I sat down at the console, it triggered a response... like I was trapped... I had to get out of there...
Was it something about the console itself?
No... it seemed disconnected somehow... maybe it's something I dreamed...
Wil... you're the third person today who's come to me with something like this... an intense emotional response provoked by an object...
Did anyone know why they had that reaction?
No... they couldn't explain it any more than you could... At this point, I'm not willing to say it's coincidence.
Maybe we should all get together.
Talking about it might help you understand the response... I'm going to find out if anyone else on the ship has been having experiences like this...
Wil... you said you had an unusual reaction when you sat down at the console. What was it like?
It's hard to describe... it was vague... like the way you recall a dream... I remember the sensation of being trapped... and something about a smooth surface...
Can anyone else describe what they felt?
I had a similar response... to a pair of scissors.
Have you had any dreams about scissors recently?
I may have... I do not have a distinct memory of it...
When my VISOR cut out in the Cargo Bay, I had a weird feeling too... something about a smooth surface... Smooth... and cold... I think it was cold...
Yes, cold...
It was elevated... a platform...
Right... a bench...
Or a table...
It sounds like you've all had a similar experience... Do you remember anything more about it besides the table?
Maybe there's a way we can help ourselves remember more...
You all remember a table... let's start with that... Computer -- show me a table...
There are five thousand forty-seven classifications of tables on file. Specify design parameters.
Can you remember anything specific about the table? You mentioned it was cold, and smooth... Do you remember what shape it was?
Long... it was long...
Yeah... a rectangular shape...
Computer -- create a rectangular conference table.
It's too high... Computer... decrease table height by... twenty-five percent...
No... the table was smaller... and it was inclined...
Computer -- decrease the table's surface area by... twenty percent... And incline the top... fifteen degrees...
It wasn't made of wood... it was smoother... more metallic...
Computer -- make this a metal table.
That's starting to look right...
Was there anything else in the room? Furniture... chairs... a door... other people...
No... it was dark...
Dark, right... you couldn't see beyond the table...
Computer -- lower the surrounding light level.
There was a light right in my face... a bright light... Computer -- give me a bright light... right above the table...
Specify light source.
I couldn't tell.. it was above me... an overhead lamp...
Estimated distance of light source.
I don't know... It seemed like it was at least... two, three meters above...
Brighter...
Brighter.
Wil... you said you were uneasy when you sat down at the Conn position...
Yeah... I felt trapped by the console... But it wasn't like this... there was something else here...
A restraint of some kind?
Yes... a restraint... it came down over my legs... No, no... my chest... it came across my chest...
It was holding you down...
Yes... it was part of the table...
Here... right here...
Computer -- create a restraining arm... attached to the right side of the table, at the mid-point...
Was it like that?
Computer -- put controls on the restraint... a control panel... lights...
There was something else here... above me... a metal swing arm... Computer -- create a metal swing-arm, double-jointed, total length one meter... Connect it to the head of the table...
There was something attached to it... A tool of some sort... scissor-like...
Computer -- produce a pair of scissors... attached to the armature...
The handle is wrong... ... It wasn't scissors... Computer -- make the handle a single grip... ten centimeters long... solid metal...
Make one blade longer... and curved inward...
Give the second blade a... jagged edge...
Tetryons... the same particles in the Cargo Bay...
I have completed my self-diagnostic, and confirmed that I was not aboard the Enterprise for ninety minutes, seventeen seconds yesterday afternoon.
Explanation?

Whenever I am on the ship, the warp field leaves an electromagnetic signature on my internal servo fluid system. Yesterday, between twelve fifty-four and fourteen twenty-six hours that signature is missing.
Computer -- are there any crewmembers missing from the Enterprise?
There are two crewmembers unaccounted for.
Identify them.
Lieutenant Edward Hagler and Ensign Sariel Rager.
When did they leave?
They have not been present since twenty-three thirty-two hours.
How did they leave?
Method of departure unknown.
Picard to Bridge.
Bridge here.
Raise shields and maintain a Level Four security alert -- I want to know if anyone goes on or off this ship.
Aye sir.
Mister La Forge, Mister Data -- I believe if we find the source of those tetryon emissions, we may also find our missing crewmembers.
We'll get on it, sir.
Doctor Crusher -- you'd better take a look at this...
My God...
What is it?
Commander... it looks as though your arm has been severed and reattached.
What?
The skeletal structure in your radius and ulna is offset by point zero two microns... Your arm has been amputated... then surgically reattached.
Any progress, Lieutenant?
Take a look at this...
Data -- the tetryon emissions have intensified. They seem to be focusing in this direction...
(continuing, re: rupture) ... coalescing here... they're reading as a point of subspace energy.
It appears to be the beginnings of a spatial rupture.
The way the tetryon emissions are modulating... it's like somebody is controlling the flow of energy...
Data... some of the signals from the modifications I made to the sensor array dipped pretty deep into subspace...
Maybe they caught somebody's attention...
At the rate the rupture is expanding, we are in danger of a hull breach.
Let's try surrounding it with a subspace containment field...
Other than the tetryon emissions in Cargo Bay Four, none of the internal sensors recorded anything unusual over the past three days.
Initiate a metallurgical analysis of the ship's hull -- subspace field incursions might have left a trace.
Captain -- sensors indicate that Lieutenant Hagler has returned to the Enterprise. He is in his quarters, Deck Seven, Section Nineteen.
Computer -- emergency entry, Chief Medical Officer Beverly Crusher.
(hits communicator, urgent) Crusher to Sickbay -- get a plasma infusion unit to Deck Seven, Section Nineteen!
His blood is transforming into some sort of... liquid polymer...
We've set up a containment field in Cargo Bay Four. But the rupture just keeps expanding. I'd say we've got another five or six hours before it breaches the hull.
Can we still beam the affected sections into space?
No sir. The spatial rupture is creating severe nucleonic interference. It is impossible to obtain a positive lock on the bulkheads.
Has your analysis suggested any way to seal the rupture?
We think we could close the rupture by neutralizing the tetryon emissions with a coherent graviton pulse. But we'd have to do it at the source.
How do we find the source?

That's a good question. The emissions are coming from a tertiary subspace domain. But subspace has an infinite number of domains... It's like a huge honeycomb with an endless number of cells. We need to isolate the exact cell the emissions are coming from...
If someone homed in on subspace signals created by our modified sensor array... can we do the same thing to them -- track the tetryon emissions to their universe?
Tetryon particles have a random momentum. Our sensors are unable to track them.
Perhaps we could make a homing device -- something our sensors could track.
Good idea. But there's no way to get that device to the source.
Yes, there is. Give it to me.
It's pretty clear I've been taken each of the past few nights... if I'm right, there's every chance it'll happen again tonight.

If you had a homing device, we could track it to your location in subspace... then, as soon as they send you back to the ship... we could transmit the graviton pulse and neutralize the tetryon emissions...
If they send him back. Ensign Rager still hasn't been returned...
They're going to take me whether I want to go or not.
We'll wait as long as we can for you to be returned, Number One. But as soon the spatial rupture threatens the ship... we'll have to transmit that graviton pulse.
Understood.
Perhaps we can give you an advantage... a way of keeping you conscious after they take you...
Doctor -- can you develop a counter-agent to the neuro-sedative they've been giving the crew?
I could try a neuro-stimulant -- but the dosage would have to be pretty high to counter the effects. It might be risky.
It's a risk I'm willing to take.
Make it so. Mister La Forge -- begin work on a homing device.
It should be enough to ward off their neuro-sedative for about twelve hours.
I hope that's enough.
It'll have to be. I can't risk giving you a higher dosage.
I've locked the tricorder into continuous scan. That way, it'll keep recording whether you open it or not. Maybe you can bring back some information about their universe.
When you see this indicator light up, it means we've locked onto the signal.
Understood.
Report.
I still can't locate the homing signal... We've covered the entire upper-subspace energy band. We're extending the scan to adjacent energy levels...
Picard to Data. Your status?
The rupture has expanded another four point two percent. Without further reinforcement, containment field integrity will fail in approximately fourteen minutes.
Can you divert more power to the containment field?
I can try to augment the field with auxiliary power, but it won't be much...
Make it so.
Aye sir.
Captain -- I've located the homing signal. Locking onto it now... It's coming from a subspace energy level of sixteen point-two K-E-V...
Stand by to initiate the graviton pulse.
Graviton emitters at full power, sir. Standing by.
Picard to Data. How much time?
At the present rate, containment failure will occur in approximately nine minutes.
Captain -- the containment field is beginning to fluctuate. Failure anticipated in three minutes, eleven seconds.
We can't afford to wait any longer... Begin the graviton pulse.
Initiating pulse... now.
Data to Engineering. The graviton pulse is having an effect. The tetryon emissions have decreased by nineteen percent...
Captain -- additional subharmonics have appeared. They are reinforcing the tetryon emissions...
They appear to be counter-acting the graviton pulse... The rupture is beginning to expand again.
Looks like somebody's fighting back...
Can you strengthen the graviton pulse?
I'll try setting up a random frequency shift. If we can keep them from guessing our pulse modulation... they might not be able to compensate...
Tetryon emissions continue to increase. The rupture is still expanding. Hull breach is imminent.
(off console, frustrated) They're reacting faster than we can shift frequencies...
Shipley -- program the emitters for full spectrum pulse compression. I want to channel all of the graviton energy into a single burst... Let's see if they can handle that...
Ready, Commander.
The rupture is beginning to close.
Recharge the emitters! Let's hit them again!
Come on...
Ready.
The rupture is ninety-six percent closed.
We're almost there. One more burst should do it...
Emitters recharging...
Ready.

Captain's Log, Stardate 46119.2. The tetryon emissions in Cargo Bay Four have ceased, and there have been no further indications of alien intrusions. All Enterprise crewmembers are safe and accounted for. But we are still left with some unanswered questions...
Based on the information gathered by Commander Riker's tricorder, we have determined that the molecular structure of the alien life forms is solanogen-based.

We think that's why they couldn't come through into our space, as easily as they could take us into theirs... They needed to learn how to remodulate their cellular energy states in order to survive in our universe.
The tricorder readings indicate they created a small pocket of our universe in their lab to keep those who were abducted alive.
Like putting a fish in a bucket of water...
They were probably trying to do the same thing in Cargo Bay Four -- create a pocket of their universe in ours.
What can we do to prevent this from happening again?
It looks like they found us initially by discovering my modified sensor signal. We should warn all Starfleet ships not to make the same mistake.
Have you any idea what came through the rupture, before you were able to shut it down?
No sir. We were unable to track it once it left the Cargo Bay.
Maybe it was a probe of some kind...
Perhaps they are simply curious. Explorers, like ourselves.
Ensign Rager and I were lucky to escape... and Lieutenant Hagler's dead... I have a feeling that whoever sent that thing... was more than simply curious.

Captain's Log, Stardate 44614.6: We are approaching Starbase Three-One-Three, where we will pick up a shipment of scientific equipment for a Federation outpost in the Guernica System. At the same time --
-- we will be hosting a special guest.
You wanted to see me, Captain?
Yes, Mister La Forge. It seems that the exemplary nature of your work has caught the attention of Starfleet Command.
Well... that's very flattering. Thank you, sir.
In fact, someone is coming on board just to see some of the engine modifications you have made.
Who's that, Captain?
The Senior Design Engineer of the Theoretical Propulsion Group -- Doctor Leah Brahms.
Leah's coming here? That's terrific!
You know Doctor Brahms?
Well, of course I do! I --
I mean, I've studied her -- her schematics for years. She was responsible for a lot of the engine design on the Enterprise.
Well, it should be an enjoyable visit, then. She'll be transporting on board as soon as we arrive at the Starbase. Would you like to greet her on our behalf?
Why... yes, Captain. I'd be happy to serve that function.
You're gonna wear that uniform out if you keep swatting at it...
I guess I'm a little nervous... it's not every day a man comes face to face with a dream...
Remember... about a year ago... when we were caught in that booby-trap the Menthars set?
Yes...
While we were trying to get out of it, I went to the holodeck to study an engine prototype that was built when the Enterprise was first designed...
Uh-huh...
And the computer... well, it gave me an image of the engine... but it also created a hologram of the designer. Doctor Leah Brahms.
So... you met a computer-simulated female...
But what a computer-simulated female... She was brilliant, of course... but warm, friendly...
We worked like one person... what I didn't think of, she did... I'd start sentences, she'd finish them. It was just so -- comfortable...
Okay, I know it was just a holographic image... but the computer was able to incorporate personality traits from her Starfleet record.
We all fall in love with our fantasies, from time to time, La Forge...
You've got it wrong, Guinan. I'm not necessarily expecting anything romantic. I just know that, whatever else, Leah Brahms and I will be good friends.
Doctor Brahms is ready to transport, sir.
Okay. Bring her over.
Hi!
I mean... welcome aboard, Doctor Brahms. I'm Lieutenant Commander Geordi La Forge. Chief Engineer.
La Forge. So you're the one who's fouled up my engine design.
... the matter/anti-matter ratio has been changed... the mixture isn't as rich as regulations dictate.
Experience has shown me that too high a ratio diminishes efficiency. I worked with the mixture until I got the right balance.
The magnetic plasma transfer to the warp field generators doesn't correspond to the recommended specs.
Right. Again, I adjusted the flow... sometimes in space things work a little differently than they do on the drawing board.
Is that a criticism, Commander?
No, of course not. It's just... a well-known fact. There's theory... and there's application. They don't always jibe.
You've charted a completely new swap-out schedule for main component replacement...
You bet. I found the Starfleet estimates of MTBF units were unrealistic. I determined my own schedule based on observation and experience.
Is that going to be your only defense, Commander? That same tired rhetoric... "Out here in the field we learn things you designers couldn't possibly understand... "
In the first place, Doctor, I'm not aware of needing any defense... in the second place --
Doctor Brahms... you have an incoming message on subspace...
I'd like to hear this message privately.
In my office. Be my guest.
Commander, I am picking up some unusual readings from the Alpha Omicron system.
At this range, all I can discern is that it is an asymmetrical field of intense energy.
What type of radiation signature?
Unknown, sir. Commander, the Alpha Omicron system has not yet been charted. I recommend that we take this opportunity for further research.
We're way ahead of schedule... Alter course for Alpha Omicron.
The anomaly is orbiting the seventh planet. It is a mass of plasma energy contained within discrete boundaries by an outer covering of silicates, actinides, and carbonaceaous chondrites.
On screen.
Magnify.
Is it a ship?
It does not conform to any known design.
Any records of similar phenomena in Starfleet listings?
None, sir. This has never been seen before.
Ensign Rager, ahead one quarter impulse. Bring us into orbit around the seventh planet. Maintain a relative distance of ten kilometers from the object.
Alert all science labs to standby. They should be coordinating their efforts with Commander Data.
Aye, sir.
Doctor Brahms... there's no reason for us to argue... we're both on the same side, here...
I'm aware of that...
So, why don't I take you on a little tour... show you the adjustments I've made... why I think they work... and... we can start pulling together on this.
Okay... for instance, here in the dilithium chamber...
What happened here? Who did this?
You remember, the crystal's been reoriented to adjust the direction of the lattice structure.
Remember? Why would I remember?
Right, why would you? The ship was having some difficulties, so we made the modification. Hoping it would work. And... it did.
So it was your idea?
Well, not exclusively...
It's curious... this modification was actually due to be introduced...
(nodding, finishing her sentence) ... in the next class starship.
Yes... how did you know?

I didn't... It was the next logical step. Doctor, sometimes we have to fly by the seat of our pants out here... and it stands to reason that now and then we're gonna come up with the same solutions you do...

Listen. I've got a personnel review scheduled to start in about five minutes, and it's been a long day for you. How about we... we get together later. Sort of... plan our agenda for the next day or two.
Agenda?
What it is we want to accomplish... the best way to go about it... and -- get to know each other. It might make things easier.
Maybe you're right...
Okay -- nineteen hundred hours... my quarters. Maybe we'll even have a bite to eat... I make great fungilli.
I love fungilli.
Is that right... ?
Sensors are having difficulty penetrating the interior. However, the pattern of radiated output suggests a coherent system of energy storage and utilization.
Then it was constructed by someone?
It is a possibility, sir. However, sensor data gathered thus far suggests this is a naturally occurring phenomenon with biological properties.
A lifeform?
Yes, Captain.
"Asked the child of the stranger without any name... whither you go... and whence you came?"
"To the child's delight the answer came clear... To the end I go for it all starts here."
It seems we were bread and buttered on the same nursery rhymes, Mister Worf.
Mister Data, prepare three class five probes for launch. Mister Worf, begin compiling readings for transmission to Starfleet Headquarters. Ensign... aft thrusters. Standard observation posture.
What would it be like, Counselor... no ship, no bulky spacesuit... just to live between the stars... and know that the entire galaxy was your home... ?
We are being probed. Recommend we raise shields, sir...
Negative. If we're curious about it, it has a right to be curious about us... Counselor, is this "curiosity" motivated by instinct or intelligence?
It's impossible to tell, Captain.
Change in readings, Captain. The lifeform has increased its energy output by fifty percent.
It is moving toward us, sir!
Reverse course, Ensign, easily... three hundred k.p.h. Nothing to alarm or provoke it...
Aye, sir...
We are being held, in an energy damping field, sir.
Raise shields.
No effect, Captain.
Reverse power, full impulse.
Impulse engines at full power.
No change in our position.
Red Alert!
Commander La Forge, prepare to initiate the warp drive.
Sorry, Captain... there's too much inteference to form a warp field.
Warning. Radiation levels at sixty-five millirads per minute and rising.
Riker to Doctor Crusher.
Go ahead, Commander.
All decks are to begin radiation protocol.
Acknowledged. Crusher out.
Warning. Radiation levels at three hundred millirads per minute and rising. Lethal exposure in one minute.
Mister Worf... ready main phasers... minimum power.
Ready.
Fire.
Radiation levels dropping back to normal, Captain.
The energy patterns are breaking down... the lifeform's radiation signature is no longer stable.
Energy output is negligible... radiation patterns are no longer coherent. I believe it is dead, sir.

We are out here to explore, to make contact with other lifeforms, to establish peaceful relations, but not to interfere and absolutely not to destroy. And yet look what we have just done -- what I have just done.
Captain, everything you did was consistent with established Starfleet procedures... what happened was an accident... unavoidable...
The Bridge is yours, Number One.
Captain, sensors are picking up a new energy reading from the lifeform.
Elaborate, Mister Data...
There is a new concentration of ionizing radiation growing in the center of its body.
Then -- perhaps it's still alive...
Computer... subdued lighting.
No, no, too much. I just want it -- nice. You know. Cozy.
Please state your request in precise candlepower.
It's not a matter of precision, it's a matter of... mood. Brighter than this.
More... more... a little more -- there! That's perfect. Now, music... maybe a little soft jazz...
No... not right... maybe -- oh, I got it! Of course -- Brahms! A piano etude...
No, that's corny. Probably everybody tries that... computer... how about... guitar. Classical guitar. Anybody.
Come on in!
Oh, you changed...
Well, you know the uniform is so... formal...
(an observation, not a compliment) You're less formal than any Starfleet officer I've ever met, Lieutenant.
Am I? I just wanted to make you... feel more comfortable.
I'm fine. Thank you.
You know... your hair is different...
Different than a few hours ago?
No, no... I mean... different than... I expected. From your Starfleet records...
Oh. Yes... I used to wear it up... Why would you need to see my personnel file... ?
It's just... standard procedure for guests coming aboard... protocol.
Nothing specific... actually.
Please. Sit down. Would you like anything to drink?
No, thank you.
Commander La Forge... if I seem to you somewhat... unyielding... in my views -- it's because I care so very much about my work.
I know that.
Well, to be honest, some people find me cold, cerebral, lacking in humor...
I'm sure they're wrong.
Well, I... try... not to be that way. But when it comes to my designs, to my engines... especially the ones on the Enterprise...
... they're like your children.
Yes... exactly...
So naturally you're a little possessive about them.
You -- understand that?
Sure. I feel a little like that myself.
That's amazing. I don't think anyone has ever...
Sometimes I'm more comfortable with engine schematics than with people.
Maybe you just haven't met the right people.
I'm starving... why don't we have some dinner.
Commander --
Please. Call me Geordi.
I'm sorry, I hope you didn't go to a lot of trouble, but I can't stay.
You can't --?
I just don't feel it's appropriate.

I'll meet you at oh-eight-hundred tomorrow. I'm preparing a list of the discrepancies I've identified in your modifications. I hope -- now that we've reached an understanding -- that you'll be prepared to discuss them with me in a more objective fashion.
Well, sure...
Thank you. Good night, Commander.
Computer -- turn up the damn lights. And get rid of that stupid guitar.
This new concentration of energy was detected only after the surrounding material became inert.
Could this be some sort of... tissue regeneration?
The radiation signature is similar to the original pattern, but there are significant differences.
Some kind of reaction to our phaser fire, perhaps...
I believe this is separate and self-contained within the body of the dead lifeform.
Another entity... ?
Yessir. It appears to be a smaller, less developed version of the original creature.
No wonder it attacked us. It was about to give birth.

It's dangerous to generalize about new lifeforms... but based on my experience with other beings that bear their young in this manner, I'd say the offspring is still premature. Otherwise, it would be able to break through the outer body shell of the parent.
Will this... child be able to survive on its own without the parent?
There's no way to tell. We don't have enough information about the bio-functions of the adult, much less the child.
Is there something we can do to help?
If we were in Sickbay, I'd try a Cesarean section... the first priority is to free it from the parent's body.
We could use our phasers like a scalpel...
Yes... that might work...
I advise against this, Captain. The parent proved to be a threat to the ship... we do not know how the offspring will react.
Your objection is noted... but we are directly responsible for the death of the parent. We cannot simply walk away now. We'll proceed at your discretion, Doctor.
Good morning!
Morning.
The first thing I'd like to do is inspect the power transfer conduits.
You realize the only way to inspect them is to crawl inside...
I designed them, Commander... I know what's involved.
Watch out for the power taps.
The acoustic signature doesn't sound right.
You're probably the only other person in the galaxy who could pick that up.
What's causing it?
It's right up here.
I've never seen anything like this... what is it?
A mid-range phase adjuster... it puts the plasma back into phase after inertial distortion.
This has never been done before. I don't think it's ever been conceived of before. You should write a scientific paper.
That's not my strong suit, Doctor...
But this kind of refinement should be shared... and you deserve the credit for it...
Maybe we could collaborate. Writing is one of your strong points.
Commander La Forge... ever since I came on board, there's been something a little peculiar in your attitude. You seem to know things about me even though we've never met.
I... studied you. Your writings, your Starfleet file. I've admired you. Your work.
I'm flattered, but...
I've looked forward to meeting you for a long time...
And I'd like to think -- that we could get to be friends. Good friends.
I thought you knew... you seem to know everything else about me... but Commander... if I'm hearing what I think I am, then you should know... I'm married.
Set phaser power to three percent, narrow beam.
Three percent.
All right... here we go.
First incision is complete.
Ideally, the offspring should be able to push through the outer shell on its own now.
It needs a little more help.
We've done all we can. I don't want to risk hitting the child by accident.
Come on... you can do it...
Captain, I'd like to announce the birth of a large baby... something.
Well done, Doctor. Well done.

A glitch, a malfunction in the holodeck... it's the only explanation I can think of... it's a miracle we ever got out of that booby-trap alive... how could it have been so far off? It was based on every piece of information on record about Leah Brahms... okay, with an admitted margin for error... but this is an error that's a light year wide...
Not what you hoped for, huh?

Hoped for... ? She's about as friendly as a Circassian Plague Cat... all she cares about is her work... she hates what I've done to her engines... and to top it off -- she's married! The computer never even told me she was married...
Computer problem, huh...
Must've been...
Maybe it was your old VISOR...
What are you talking about?
The VISOR you wore on the holodeck with her.
This is the same VISOR.
Really? I figured you were wearing the one that lets you see what you want to see.
What's that supposed to mean?
You saw exactly what you wanted to see in the holodeck... Sure, the computer made it look like her, added personality... but when it came to your relationship together, you filled in the blanks...
Here you had this perfectly wonderful fantasy... and now the real Leah comes along and ruins it.
She's done the most heartless, despicable thing one person can do to another -- she didn't live up to your expectations.
Take a hard look through your VISOR, La Forge... see her for who she really is... not what you want her to be.
The lifeform's patterns are stable, Captain. It seems able to withstand the solar radiation without difficulty.
Good. Ensign Rager, set course for the Guernica system.
Aye, sir...
We're not staying?
No. We've done what we can to help... now it's time to move on. This... child will live the rest of its life without any further interference from us.
It might be wise to put some distance between us before initiating the warp drive.
Very well. Five hundred k.p.h., Ensign. Engage.
Captain, it's following us... maintaining a distance of four kilometers directly astern.
Seventeen degrees to port, Ensign Rager.
Aye, sir.
It's turning with us, sir.
Increase to one half impulse.
It is matching our velocity.
(with sudden understanding) It's imprinted on us. It thinks the Enterprise is... its mother.
A change in energy readings, sir. I am reading an internal buildup of gamma particles in---
Its velocity is increasing... it's moving directly toward the ship!
Evasive maneuvers, full...
Report...
Minor damage...
Sir, the creature is now in direct contact with the hull.
On screen.
Data?
Sir, the lifeform is draining energy directly from the fusion reactors.
Feeding off the energy of the Enterprise as it would from its mother.
What action should we take, Captain?
None, Lieutenant. None at all.

Captain's log, supplemental. Since the newborn has attached itself to the hull, it has been making greater and greater demands on the ship's energy, but we have been able to temporarily stabilize our power systems.
How long before the power drain becomes critical, Mister La Forge?
If it continues to increase at the current rate, six, seven hours, maybe...
We may be able to modify the engines to extend that a little longer, Captain.
Your help would be appreciated, Doctor.
By then, maybe Junior won't need us any more.
Data, is there any way to determine what the destination of the parent might have been?
I can attempt to extrapolate from the heading it was on when we encountered it, sir.
(understanding what Picard is thinking) Perhaps it was on the way to a safe and supportive environment for its newborn.
We might be able to deliver it to the same destination.
Which raises the question of how to get Junior off the hull when we get there...
It's almost completely covering the door of shuttlebay two. If we open the door and deactivate the atmospheric force field...
... the pressure from inside the ship might push it away from the hull.
Make it so.
Is the appellation "Junior" to be the lifeform's official name from now on?
No. It's not.
We can save a lot of energy just by improving engine efficiency...
We've run into similar problems before... that's actually why I reoriented the dilithium crystal...
And why you added that mid-range phase adjuster...
Right.
Commander... it seems you've made more modifications than I'm aware of. Do you have a file on all the work you've done?
Sure. It's in the computer --
Picard to La Forge...
La Forge here...
Commander, I need to see you on the Bridge.
Yes, sir, be right there. You go ahead, Doctor... Ensign Pavlik can show you the file on the engine modifications.
Phase coils upgraded to fifty-five field densities... plasma inducers interlinked with generator... Ensign, would there be any other files with data on the original engine specifications?
I believe so, Doctor...
This file utilizes the prototype engine schematic...
(nods, interpreting the information on the screen for her) It's a holographic program set in the drafting room at Utopia Planitia.
Perfect. I'll run it on Holodeck Three.
Computer... replay program Nine-One-Four-Zero... engine schematic at Utopia Planitia...
Program loaded and ready.
She went where?
Holodeck Three, sir... I didn't think there was anything wrong with her seeing the file...
Of course not... nothing at all...
I'm with you every day, Geordi. Every time you look at this engine, you're looking at me. Every time you touch it, it's me.
Computer, freeze program.
Now... I understand...
No, you don't... it wasn't the way it might look...

I called up a replay of the program file. I was all ready to compliment you again, Commander... for constructing a program which contained the prototype engine... so you'd always have a base-line reference point for your modifications...
And then I find... it's all about a -- fantasy plaything...
It's not like that, I swear --
I am outraged by this. I have been -- invaded. Violated. How dare you use me like this? How far did it go, anyway? Was it good for you?
Nothing like that happened. It was a professional collaboration.
Oh, I can tell -- "Every time you touch the engine, it's me... " Real professional.
If you watched the whole program, you saw what it was... we worked together to solve a problem. In a crisis situation --
How do I know that's all there was? What other programs did you create? You could have dozens of them, one for every day of the week, one for every mood --

Ever since you came on board, you've been badgering me... and I've taken it. I've shown you courtesy, and respect, and a hell of a lot of patience. I've tried to understand you and I've tried to get along with you...
And in return, you've accused me, tried and convicted me without bothering to hear my side of it. So -- I'm guilty, okay? But not of what you think... of something much worse...
I'm guilty of reaching out to you... of hoping we could connect... I'm guilty of a terrible crime, Doctor -- I offered you friendship.
Its total volume has increased by eight point five percent in the last three hours. I am now reading it as forty-six million cubic meters.
Captain, I have completed the analysis of the parent's course through this system.
It was heading for an asteroid belt...
Ensign Rager, set course two five nine mark three one eight, one half impulse.
Aye, sir.
Hold position five hundred kilometers from the periphery of the asteroid field...
Aye, sir.
Difficulty getting a clear sensor reading beyond four thousand kilometers.

The asteroids contain large quantities of meklinite, which is interferring with our scanners. I am also detecting traces of Kefnium, a compound which was found in the parent being's outer shell. It is likely that the asteroids provide sustenance for this lifeform.
We could leave the child here. If Data's right, it would have an ample supply of food.
Agreed. Mister La Forge, are you ready to separate our guest from the hull?
Ready, Captain.
Proceed.
I'm deactivating the atmospheric force field now, Captain.
Engineering, report!
The power drain just jumped to ninety-three percent, sir.
Captain, the offspring is emitting a high frequency radio transmission.
Is it trying to communicate?
The power drain is increasing... approaching auto-shutdown.
Take the engines off-line. Supplement with auxiliary power.
All decks go to emergency condition seven. Life support and critical operations only.
Mister La Forge, what is your status?
I'm sorry, Captain... the bay's been completely depressurized, but... it's still hanging on.
I am detecting other radio transmissions, Captain.
Sensors detecting movement within the asteroid field... distance, two million kilometers, bearing two-five-seven mark one-six-one.
On screen.
At their current speed, the entities will intercept us in ten minutes, thirty-one seconds.
Weapons status?
Auxiliary power only... two seconds phaser fire available.
Ensign... power readings.
We're on auxiliary generators... life support is functioning, that's about all...
Keep your eye on the generator console. We've got less than six minutes to get that baby off our back before his relatives get here...
Whatever we try, junior responds by sucking up more energy...
I have a thought, Commander...
If you're interested...
Of course. What is it?
If the baby is nursing, perhaps what we need -- is to find a way to sour the milk.
I'm listening.
If we could contaminate the energy he's feeding on...
... make it unpalatable somehow...
... but the emergency generators are all we've got...
... and how do we modify them without losing life support?
Exactly... unless...
What?
This is a space baby, right? I mean, these creatures are born, live, and die in interstellar space?
Apparently...
Okay. All matter in space vibrates in a specific radiation band...
Twenty-one centimeters...
That's good, Commander, that's very good. We could alter the power frequency so it's completely foreign to the lifeform's natural vibrations...
And that might be just enough to pour a little vinegar in baby's milk.
We'll have to be careful... if we upset it this time, we might lose auxiliary power too.
If we're gradual enough, it won't be a shock. Hopefully it'll just lose interest.
La Forge to Bridge...
Go ahead.
Doctor Brahms and I have a plan, Captain.
Two minutes until the creatures intercept, sir.
Captain, we're ready down here.
Proceed.
Lowering wavelength in the energy system, now...
Reading eighteen... fifteen... thirteen... eleven... eight... five... three... now at the two centimeter level...
Any reaction, Bridge?
Negative. I detect no reduction in the lifeform's rate of energy consumption.
One minute thirty seconds to intercept.
Okay... not sour enough. Leah, take it down further.
Reading one... point eight... point four... point two...
I guess it noticed what we're doing.
The lifeform is emitting its high frequency transmission... energy consumption is rising...
Captain -- the creatures are accelerating their approach... they're changing color!
Mister La Forge --
Just a little more time, Captain--! Nudge it down... toward point-oh-two...
Intercept in thirty seconds.
Point oh-eight... oh-five... oh-three... now at point oh-two centimeters...
Auxiliary generators are losing power, Captain...
The entity has disengaged, sir.
Power returning to normal levels, Captain.
Bring the engines on line. And take us out of here.
Mister La Forge... Doctor Brahms... congratulations. You have weaned the baby.
Good work.
You, too.
Yeah... yeah, I'll admit... I did get a little... attached to that lady in the holodeck...
The computer never told you that I was married...
I never asked... and the computer is notorious for not volunteering information... tell me about him...
My husband? His name is Michael... he's an engineer on Garran-four... ... you'd like him.
I'm sure...
You remind me of him actually.
I do?
I really owe you an apology, Geordi.
No you don't. I should have told you straight out...
But if you had, I never would've seen the look on your face when you walked in on me... and me... in the holodeck...
The look on my face... ? The look on your face, I'll remember that a long time.
I wouldn't change a thing... Except the way I behaved... I guess I came here with my own set of preconceptions about you...
I'm just glad I finally got the chance to know you... the real you.
Me too. Tell me... am I... really that different than my image in the holodeck?
Not so different... not so different at all.
Worf to La Forge... there's an incoming message on subspace for Doctor Brahms...
My husband...
Acknowledged, Worf. La Forge out.

It's been five months since Marc's accident. I haven't missed a single hour of my duties. I've volunteered for extra time in the nursery. My language studies are better than they've ever been. Someone else might have given in -- but I didn't.
"Given in" to what?
Death is a normal part of life. Maybe some of us are better at facing that than others.
Or maybe some of us aren't really facing it at all.
Sometimes, we suffer more than our suffering requires.
What do you mean?
Recovery from a great loss involves a great deal of pain. If we try to avoid that pain we only make it harder on ourselves in the long run.
But I feel fine.
Then why did you come to see me?
I told you. I just wanted to... check in.
Today would have been your husband's thirty-eighth birthday.
You keep excellent records, Deanna.
Last night. I dreamt Marc was with me, celebrating. I held him. I was so glad this nonsense was finally over. Then I woke up -- Alone. And I knew he was dead. For the first time, I knew it...
I looked everywhere for something that belonged to him -- anything. I forgot that after the funeral I told them to take it all away.
You were there, Deanna. What in the world was I thinking?
They didn't take everything away.
How did you know... ? How did you know... ?
... An ancient trail along the Kabul River in the Himalayas... it's a wonderful program... Will, it'll do you good to get a little fresh Holodeck air...
Thanks anyway, but my horsemanship is a little too rusty to take on the Himalayas.
Nonsense. We'll program an appropriately docile steed for you and...
Captain! Sensors indicate a vast field of...
Of what, Lieutenant?
It's gone. But something did appear to be directly in our path.
Deflector shields are not encountering elevated levels of interstellar matter...
A sensor echo, Data?
Uncertain... I have no unusual readings, Commander.
I promise I'll come by to see you tomorrow. Deanna, are you alright?
What... ?
You faded out there for a second.
No, I'm okay. Very... tired, that's all.
You're sure?
Yes... Will I see you tomorrow?
Tomorrow. Thank you, Deanna.
Of course.
An aggregate field of plane-polarized objects has just appeared... And disappeared.
Recommend we run a diagnostic on the forward sensor array. We don't want a ghost tailing us all the way to T'lli Beta.
I'm not convinced it is a ghost, Commander. There may be something there...
Ensign Allenby, full stop. We'll investigate both possibilities.
Aye, sir.
Captain's log, stardate 44356.9. Sensor diagnostic has been completed and indicates that all systems are normal. There remains no explanation for the images which appeared in our path.
I have completed another full scan of the area, sir. There is no further indication of the anomaly...
Prepare to resume course to T'lli Beta, Ensign. Mister Data, what velocity will put us back on schedule?
An immediate resumption of our course at warp six will place us in the T'lli Beta system in six days, thirteen hours and forty-seven minutes.
What, no seconds?
I have discovered, Sir, a certain level of impatience when I calculate a lengthy time interval to the nearest second. However, if you wish...
No, no. Minutes is fine.
Ensign, set course and stand ready at warp six.
Aye, Sir.
Engage.
Riker to Engineering... what the hell happened, Geordi?
Checking... looks like the field collapsed before we could enter warp...
Reason?
Damned if I know. There doesn't seem to be any permanent damage to the nacelles. Recommend full stop while I check it out...
Back to full stop, Ensign.
Aye, sir.
All decks reporting. Minor injuries only.
Damage?
None.
Weapons and shields normal.
Go to yellow alert.
Captain... we've started moving again... something's pulling us...
Troi to Doctor Crusher.
Yes, Deanna?
Beverly, I'm feeling very... dizzy...
Did you hit your head... ?
I'm not sure. I'm not sure what happened.
Lie down, breathe deeply, stay calm... we've got calls coming in from all over the ship. I'll be there as soon as I can.
New heading confirmed: zero-two-five mark two-seven-three. Speed is holding at one-tenth impulse...
Whatever's pulling us sure isn't in a hurry...
Picard to La Forge.
Go ahead, Captain.
If your engines are functional, we'll attempt to break free.
Everything down here seems normal enough, sir... but I suggest we take it a little slower this time...
Ensign, bring us around ninety degrees to starboard from our current heading...
New course laid in, ninety degrees to starboard.
One-quarter impulse. Engage.
Aye,sir.
Nothing, Captain. Course and speed are unaffected.
One-half impulse.
No change.
Full impulse... rotate heading in five degree increments.
Aye, sir.
La Forge?
There's nothing wrong down here! The engines are fine!
Integrity field stress now exceeding eighty-two million kilo-dynes. Recommend immediate shutdown.
Ensign.
All engines down.
We're still being pulled. Same heading. Same speed.
I got here as quickly as I could. We've got a Sickbay filled with headaches. How are you?
I was feeling intense pain when I first called you. Now it's gone. But I'm still a bit... foggy.
I'd like to take you to Sickbay and run an internuncial series. I'm getting some unusual readings. Can you walk?
All senior staff report to the Observation Lounge.
Are you up to that?
Yes, I think so.
Is something wrong?
No, I'm fine.
Could it be some sort of tractor beam?
No other ship is indicated.
Mister Worf, your analysis.
